Note the red dot in the figure, you can see that in the state C,$P_{C}=1\times10^{5}P_{a}$ and $V_{C}=3\times10^{-3}m^{3}$
Note the red dot in the figure, you can see that in the state A,$P_{A}=3\times10^{5}P_{a}$ and $V_{A}=1\times10^{-3}m^{3}$
According to the ideal gas equation of state $\frac{P_{A}V_{A}}{T_{A}}=\frac{P_{C}V_{C}}{T_{C}}$, $T_{C}=300k$ can be obtained

From A to C, the volume of the gas decreases, and the outside world does positive work on the gas, and the area enclosed by the p-V plot line and the horizontal axis can be obtained $W=p\Delta V=1\times10^{5}\times(3\times10^{-3}-1\times10^{-3})\mathrm{J=200J}$

Since $T_{A}=T_{C}$, the internal energy of the gas in states A and C is equal, thus $\Delta U=0$. According to the first law of thermodynamics, $\Delta U=W+Q$, it can be deduced that $\mathrm{Q=200J}$
